title: How to Build a Pen Drive

steps.title: Protect your work surface.
steps.content: Protect your work surface. Spread a cloth or a newspaper to avoid leaving marks.

steps.title: Acquire a flash memory chip.
steps.content: Acquire a flash memory chip. There are many such chips available. This chip will be the heart of your Pen Drive.

steps.title: Use a Drill to cut the plastic to the right size, depending on your chip.
steps.content: Use a Drill to cut the plastic to the right size, depending on your chip. Make sure that the combined size of both does not exceed the maximum size of a standard USB Connector. It is a good idea to wear goggles while doing this, as drill bits and flashing can fly.

steps.title: Align the plastic case and the chip.
steps.content: Align the plastic case and the chip. Cut off any excess plastic. Remember to maintain absolute precision.

steps.title: Glue the plastic to the chip, keeping the chip connector side down, so as not to cover it up.
steps.content: Glue the plastic to the chip, keeping the chip connector side down, so as not to cover it up. Avoid using normal glue or superglue, this can leave stains on your work area and might mess up the components. Use a glue made to glue plastics together.

steps.title: Join the two components firmly using a vice, clamp, or just by pressing them together between your palms.
steps.content: Join the two components firmly using a vice, clamp, or just by pressing them together between your palms. Be very careful not to mess up the alignment.

steps.title: Wait for the glue to dry.
steps.content: Wait for the glue to dry. Leave your Pen Drive for a while as the glue dries. Keep it under a fan to help it dry faster.

steps.title: Measure the USB connector.
steps.content: Measure the USB connector. Leave a 2 centimeter (0.8 in) gap starting from the front of the pen drive, making sure not to cover the connector. It is better to leave more gap than less gap, as your pen drive may not go in at all if improperly designed.

steps.title: Draw a rough dividing line, dividing the pen drive into two parts, head and body.
steps.content: Draw a rough dividing line, dividing the pen drive into two parts, head and body. The head of the pen drive is the part that plugs into the computer, whereas the body stays outside and can be decorated. Use the measurement you made in the previous step to facilitate this task.

steps.title: Remember to only decorate the body.
steps.content: Remember to only decorate the body. All the steps below should be applied only to the body of the pen drive.

steps.title: Encase the pen drive.
steps.content: Encase the pen drive. This is not necessary, but can go a long way toward protecting your pen drive from mechanical damage. It also makes it look better. This should be done only to the body! Follow the steps below to encase the pen drive: Lay the pen drive on your work surface, and measure its dimensions. Drill a hole of the dimensions of the pen drive into a slab of plastic. Cut out any excess plastic, leaving a border around the hole. Place the pen drive in the hole and use some glue to lock it in place, if necessary.

steps.title: Paint the pen drive in your favourite colours.
steps.content: Paint the pen drive in your favourite colours.

steps.title: Decorate it!
steps.content: Decorate it! This is up to your imagination. Here are some ideas: Put the pen drive in a 3D case Add a tag or a hole to it to use it as a keychain. Add some papier mache, or glitter.

steps.title: Decide what you want to use the pen drive for.
steps.content: Decide what you want to use the pen drive for. Pen drives have a wide variety of uses, and some of them are given below: Bootable OS Drive Simple Flash Memory Drive Portable App Drive System Restore Drive Ram Drive Encrypted Data Drive System Unlock Key

steps.title: Load the necessary software on your pen drive.
steps.content: Load the necessary software on your pen drive. If you want to use it as a bootable drive , you will need to install a bootable image of an OS (Often Linux) on it.
